thread.title: Morning Roundup: ResponsibleOhio's challenge to the Statehouse, City Council member sells law practice, why one business loves all this rain
thread.title_full: Morning Roundup: ResponsibleOhio's challenge to the Statehouse, City Council member sells law practice, why one business loves all this rain

author: Doug Buchanan
title: Morning Roundup: ResponsibleOhio's challenge to the Statehouse, City Council member sells law practice, why one business loves all this rain
text:
Morning Roundup: Kasich tells GOP to 'move on' over gay marriage Columbus City Councilwoman Eileen Paley has sold her law practice. Dublin-based Doucet & Associates Co. LPA said it had acquired the business for an undisclosed amount, enabling Paley to focus on her city council service and her race for Franklin County Municipal Court . She'll join the firm part-time to help with client transitions. "We are honored to be trusted with her client matters moving forward, and we look forward to Eileenâ€™s continued success in public service," founder and Principal Troy Doucet said in a statement. Doucet is a 12-lawyer foreclosure defense and consumer law firm with a focus on small businesses, litigation and contract disputes. A local investment advisory firm has been named among the country's best . CNBC looked at five-year investment returns, asset growth and other indicators to calculate the Top 100 Fee-Only Wealth Management Firms in the U.S., putting Columbus' United American Capital Corporation at No. 76. The firm has $4.2 billion in assets under management and posted a 50 percent five-year annualized return. It was founded in 1991 by Dennis Yacobozzi. In sports, the University of Maryland is seeing plenty of positives from its first year in the Big Ten . The Chicago Tribune reports the school is pleased with a league-best seven regular-season and conference tournament championships , plus big gains in revenue and attendance for football and basketball. "We went from one nice neighborhood to another great neighborhood," Maryland men's soccer coach Sasho Cirovski told the paper. "I can tell you nobody has been talking about the ACC around here for awhile." And not all businesses are hating all this rain. After yesterday's item about painters, pools and others impacted by 19 straight days of precipitation, we heard from Star Lanes Polaris, which is having the Best June Ever. The bowling ( and more ) attraction has seen revenue jump 33 percent this month compared with a year ago because of "increased walk-in business and last-minute events that needed to move indoors due to wet weather." It's been marketing itself as the Rain Plan for scheduled parties that need to an escape. No offense, fellas, but I really hope your good luck doesn't extend through July.
